001package nbody;
002
003/******************************************************************************
004 *  Compilation:  javac Vector.java
005 *  Execution:    java Vector
006 *
007 *  Implementation of a vector of real numbers.
008 *
009 *  This class is implemented to be immutable: once the client program
010 *  initialize a Vector, it cannot change any of its fields
011 *  (N or data[i]) either directly or indirectly. Immutability is a
012 *  very desirable feature of a data type.
013 *
014 *
015 *  % java Vector
016 *  x        =  (1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0)
017 *  y        =  (5.0, 2.0, 4.0, 1.0)
018 *  x + y    =  (6.0, 4.0, 7.0, 5.0)
019 *  10x      =  (10.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0)
020 *  |x|      =  5.477225575051661
021 *  <x, y>   =  25.0
022 *  |x - y|  =  5.0990195135927845
023 *
024 *  Note that java.util.Vector is an unrelated Java library class.
025 *
026 ******************************************************************************/
027
028public class Vector { 
029
030    private final int N;         // length of the vector
031    private final double[] data;       // array of vector's components
032
033    // create the zero vector of length N
034    public Vector(int N) {
035        this.N = N;
036        this.data = new double[N];
037    } // Vector( int )
038
039    // create a vector from an array
040    public Vector(double[] data) {
041        N = data.length;
042
043        // defensive copy so that client can't alter our copy of data[]
044        this.data = new double[N];
045        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
046            this.data[i] = data[i];
047        } // for
048    } // Vector( double [] )
049
050    // create a vector from either an array or a vararg list
051    // this constructor uses Java's vararg syntax to support
052    // a constructor that takes a variable number of arguments, such as
053    // Vector x = new Vector(1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0);
054    // Vector y = new Vector(5.0, 2.0, 4.0, 1.0);
055/*
056    public Vector(double... data) {
057        N = data.length;
058
059        // defensive copy so that client can't alter our copy of data[]
060        this.data = new double[N];
061        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
062            this.data[i] = data[i];
063    }
064*/
065    // return the length of the vector
066    public int length() {
067        return N;
068    } // length()
069
070    // return the inner product of this Vector a and b
071    public double dot(Vector that) {
072        if (this.N != that.N) {
073            throw new RuntimeException("Dimensions don't agree");
074        } // if
075        
076        double sum = 0.0;
077        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
078            sum = sum + (this.data[i] * that.data[i]);
079        return sum;
080    } // dot( Vector )
081
082    // return the Euclidean norm of this Vector
083    public double magnitude() {
084        return Math.sqrt(this.dot(this));
085    } // magnitude()
086
087    // return the Euclidean distance between this and that
088    public double distanceTo(Vector that) {
089        if (this.N != that.N) {
090            throw new RuntimeException("Dimensions don't agree");
091        } // if
092        
093        return this.minus(that).magnitude();
094    } // distanceTo( Vector )
095
096    // return this + that
097    public Vector plus(Vector that) {
098        if (this.N != that.N) {
099            throw new RuntimeException("Dimensions don't agree");
100        } // if
101        
102        Vector c = new Vector(N);
103        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
104            c.data[i] = this.data[i] + that.data[i];
105        return c;
106    } // plus( Vector )
107
108    // return this - that
109    public Vector minus(Vector that) {
110        if (this.N != that.N) {
111            throw new RuntimeException("Dimensions don't agree");
112        } // if
113        
114        Vector c = new Vector(N);
115        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
116            c.data[i] = this.data[i] - that.data[i];
117        return c;
118    } // minus( Vector )
119
120    // return the corresponding coordinate
121    public double cartesian(int i) {
122        return data[i];
123    } // cartesian( int )
124
125    // create and return a new object whose value is (this * factor)
126    public Vector times(double factor) {
127        Vector c = new Vector(N);
128        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
129            c.data[i] = factor * data[i];
130        return c;
131    } // times( double )
132
133
134    // return the corresponding unit vector
135    public Vector direction() {
136        if (this.magnitude() == 0.0) {
137            throw new RuntimeException("Zero-vector has no direction");
138        } // if
139        
140        return this.times(1.0 / this.magnitude());
141    } // direction()
142
143    // return a string representation of the vector
144    @Override
145    public String toString() {
146        StringBuilder s = new StringBuilder();
147        s.append("(");
148        for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
149            s.append(data[i]);
150            if (i < N-1) s.append(", ");
151        } // for
152        s.append(")");
153        return s.toString();
154    } // toString()
155
156
157    // test client
158    public static void main(String[] args) {
159        double[] xdata = { 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0 };
160        double[] ydata = { 5.0, 2.0, 4.0, 1.0 };
161
162        Vector x = new Vector(xdata);
163        Vector y = new Vector(ydata);
164
165        System.out.println("x        =  " + x);
166        System.out.println("y        =  " + y);
167        System.out.println("x + y    =  " + x.plus(y));
168        System.out.println("10x      =  " + x.times(10.0));
169        System.out.println("|x|      =  " + x.magnitude());
170        System.out.println("<x, y>   =  " + x.dot(y));
171        System.out.println("|x - y|  =  " + x.minus(y).magnitude());
172    } // main( String [] )
173} // Vector
